Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg

Class HeuristicGraph

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg.HeuristicGraph
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
MaxGraph, SumGraph
public abstract class HeuristicGraph extends Object implements Serializable
A heuristic graph is a data structure that represents the relationships between propositions and events in a ground problem to enable various kinds of analysis.

Heuristic graphs are inspired by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst's plan graph data structure. It represents a relaxed model of a planning problem where once a proposition becomes true it stays true forever (sometimes called the "ignore delete lists" relaxation). However, these are several important differences:

  • Since Sabre problems use fluents and are not limited to Boolean propositions, heuristic graphs represent each fluent as a set of values where values can be added to the set but never removed (sometimes called monotonic or accumulating semantics).
  • Heuristic graphs can represent numeric values, like numeric fluents and arithmetic expressions. By default, numeric values are represented as a range which implicitly includes all values between the lowest and highest value.
  • A heuristic graph does not model mutex relations. This is because mutex relations are costly to check, and heuristic graphs are designed to be fast enough to be reused frequently, such as in Jörg Hoffmann's Fast Forward heuristic.
  • Heuristic graphs generalize Blum and Furst's plan graphs as well as Blai Bonet and Héctor Geffner's additive heuristic by allowing multiple possible definitions of a node's cost. A max graph is a heuristic graph where the cost of a conjunction is the maximum cost of any of its conjuncts, similar to the levels of Blum and Furst's plan graph. A sum graph is a heuristic graph where the cost of a conjunction is the sum of the cost of its conjuncts (similar to Bonet and Geffner's additive heuristic).
Nodes in a heuristic graph can be treated like a monotonically increasing set of values that are each associated with a cost. The most common operation on a heuristic graph is to query a node about the cost of a value. For example, you can ask a nominal fluent how much it would cost for it to take on one of its many possible values. When a heuristic graph is initialized to a state, every value will have either a cost of 0 (meaning the node's expression has that value in the initial state) or positive infinity (meaning the node's expression cannot yet have that value). Each time a heuristic graph is extended, every action whose precondition has a finite cost will be added to the graph (that is, its cost will go from infinite to finite). Adding new actions may cause new expressions that previously had an infinite cost to have a finite cost. If those new actions enable new propositions, then extending the graph again may add new actions, and those actions will add new propositions, and so on. Eventually, the graph will level off, which means that no new actions can be added. Once a graph has leveled off, extend() will return false.

Some nodes represent Boolean propositions, whose sets of values can only be true and false. Examples include disjunctions, clauses, preconditions, and effects. These nodes only have a CostNode.getCost() method that returns the cost of that expression being true. Event nodes are like this too; their CostNode.getCost() method returns the cost of reaching a state where that event could occur.

Heuristic graphs can be used to explore the structural properties of a problem, such as which actions can possibly satisfy certain propositions. Heuristic graphs can also be used to check a necessary but not sufficient condition for whether a proposition is possible. Once a heuristic graph has leveled off, if a proposition is not in the graph, we can be confident that the proposition is impossible (however, we cannot be certain that a proposition is possible just because it is in the graph).

Heuristic graphs are commonly used to simplify compiled problems and in heuristics for heuristic search.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Overrides:

    • getNode

      public Node getNode(Logical logical)
      Returns the heuristic graph node associated with the given logical expression. If the node does not exist, it will be created.
      Parameters:
      logical - the logical expression to represent in the graph
      Returns:
      a node representing that logical expression (which will have that expression as its its label)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the graph cannot create a node for the given expression
      FormatException - if the logical expression is not ground

    • getConstant

      public ConstantNode getConstant(Value value)
      Returns the constant node associated with the given logical value. If the node does not exist, it will be created.
      Parameters:
      value - the logical value to represent in the graph
      Returns:
      a constant node representing that value

      Returns:

      Throws:

      public NominalFluentNode getNominalFluent(Fluent fluent)

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      the fluent node representing the fluent
      Throws:
      FormatException - if the fluent is not ground
      FormatException - if the fluent is numeric

    • getCharacters

      public Iterable<Character> getCharacters()
      Returns the characters which have utility nodes represented in the graph. The resulting collection will not include null, even if the author's utility is represented.
      Returns:
      a collection of characters whose utilities are defined in the graph

    • getUtility

      public UtilityNode getUtility()
      Returns the utility node representing the author's utility if it has been defined.
      Returns:
      a utility node representing the author's utility, or null if the author's utility has not been represented in this graph yet

    • getUtility

      public UtilityNode getUtility(Character character)
      Returns the utility node representing an character's utility if it has been defined.
      Parameters:
      character - the character whose utility representation is desired
      Returns:
      a utility node representing the character's utility, or null if the character's utility has not been represented in this graph yet

    • setUtility

      public UtilityNode setUtility(Character character, Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> utility)
      Defines a utility node for the given character using the given utility expression. To define the author's utility, the character argument should be null. This method should only be called once per character; calling it more than once per character will cause an IllegalStateException. To access an already defined utility node, use getUtility().
      Parameters:
      character - the character whose utility is being represented
      utility - a numeric expression which can be evaluated to determine how satisfied the character is with a given situation
      Returns:
      a utility node for that character representing the utility expression
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if a utility node has already been defined for the character

    • reset

      public void reset()
      Resets event node in the graph so that all costs are positive infinity, except for costs which are trivially 0 (the constant node representing true and the clause node representing the empty clause).

    • getLevels

      public double[] getLevels()
      Returns an array of all finite costs that appear anywhere in the graph (that is, the cost of any cost nodes with a finite cost and the costs of any cost sets that have values with finite costs).
      Returns:
      a sorted array of finite costs that appear in this graph

    • initialize

      public void initialize(State state)
      Resets all nodes in the graph and then initializes all fluent nodes by setting the cost of the value that fluent has in the given state to 0. After initialization, nodes that represent Boolean propositions will have a cost of 0 if they are true in the given state or positive infinity otherwise. Numeric nodes like arithmetic nodes and utility nodes will have the cost of their value in the given state set of 0, and the cost of all other values set to positive infinity.
      Parameters:
      state - the state that defines the initial value of each fluent

    • extend

      public boolean extend()
      Sets the cost of any action node which currently has an infinite cost but whose precondition has a finite cost to the cost of its precondition plus one. This method returns true if at least one new action was assigned a finite cost; otherwise, this method returns false. Once this method returns false, the heuristic graph is said to have leveled off.
      Returns:
      true if at least one action that previously has an infinite cost was assigned a finite cost, or false if the graph has leveled off
